verses.text: Listen therefore, O kings, and understand; learn, O rulers of the ends of the earth.
verses.comment: The writer addresses all those in authority, emphasizing that wisdom and understanding are not just for ordinary people, but especially for rulers. This reflects the biblical motif that leadership is a grave responsibility before God (see also Ps. 2:10).

verses.text: Pay attention, you who rule over multitudes and boast of the many nations under your sway.
verses.comment: The responsibility of rulers includes accounting for those they lead. The text asks leaders to reflect on their duties, hinting that those with more authority must also answer to a higher standard. (Compare Prov. 31:4.)

verses.text: For authority is given to you by the Lord, and power by the Most High. He will examine your works and probe your intentions.
verses.comment: All power comes from God Himself. Those who govern are ultimately accountable to Him. This verse prefigures New Testament teaching about obedience to lawful authority (see Rom. 13:1), but also the responsibility of those in authority.

verses.text: Because, though you are ministers of His kingdom, you did not govern rightly, nor keep the law, nor walk according to God’s purpose.
verses.comment: Leaders are stewards of God's kingdom. The mention of not following the law foreshadows Jesus' teaching that greater knowledge and responsibility leads to greater judgment (see Luke 12:48).

verses.text: He will come upon you terribly and swiftly, for judgment falls hard on those in high places.
verses.comment: With increased authority comes the need for increased spiritual vigilance. James 3:1 echoes this: 'Not many of you should become teachers, for you know that we who teach will be judged with greater strictness.' Similar heightened accountability extends to all authority.

verses.text: For the lowly may be forgiven out of mercy, but the mighty will be tested mightily.
verses.comment: This verse lays out the principle that responsibility is proportional to privilege and power. The moral: those entrusted with more are judged more strictly. There is also a theme here of mercy toward the humble, reflecting Jesus’ teaching.

verses.text: The Sovereign of all does not stand in awe of persons, nor show deference to greatness, because He made both great and small, and cares for all alike.
verses.comment: God is entirely impartial. Both the Old and New Testaments repeatedly teach that God shows no partiality. (See Deut. 10:17, Acts 10:34.)

verses.text: But for those in power, a stern inquiry awaits.
verses.comment: Those wielding authority have a grave duty before God. See also the parable of the rich man and Lazarus, illustrating how our earthly status is nothing in God’s eyes if we neglect righteousness.

verses.text: To you then, rulers, my words are directed, so that you may learn wisdom and not fall away.
verses.comment: The pursuit of wisdom is a safeguard against moral failure for those in authority. This verse encourages humility and docility to God's wisdom, qualities also seen in Solomon (Prov. 1:1-7).

verses.text: Those who guard what is holy will be seen as holy, and those who learn these things will find defense in them.
verses.comment: The holiness of God's people is expressed not just in belief, but in careful obedience to God's instructions. Jesus echoes this in John 17:17; God's word sanctifies.

verses.text: Therefore desire my words, yearn for them, and you will be instructed.
verses.comment: The love of God’s wisdom safeguards the soul. Meditation on the divine word is a recurring theme throughout the Psalms (cf. Ps. 119:97).

verses.text: Wisdom shines bright and never fades; she is easily seen by those who love her, and is found by those who seek her.
verses.comment: The personification of Wisdom as a radiant, feminine figure recalls Proverbs, yet also anticipates the fulfillment of divine Wisdom in Christ (see 1 Cor. 1:24).

verses.text: She hastens to make herself known to those who desire her.
verses.comment: Wisdom is not distant or hard to obtain; instead, she meets seekers halfway. This theme is picked up by Christ's own self-offering to all who desire truth.

verses.text: Whoever rises early to seek her will not grow weary; they will find her sitting at their door.
verses.comment: Diligence in seeking God’s wisdom will always be rewarded, as God’s grace is not distant but near to those who seek Him. Early rising also recalls disciplined spiritual practices.

verses.text: Thinking deeply about her is understanding’s perfection, and whoever stays awake for her will soon be free from care.
verses.comment: Contemplation and vigilance in prayer open the soul to the fullness of God's wisdom. This also hints at the value of meditative prayer and watchfulness.

verses.text: For Wisdom herself walks about seeking those worthy of her; she graciously appears on their paths and meets them in every thought.
verses.comment: This illustrates the initiative of divine Wisdom searching out souls, prefiguring God’s desire to dwell with His people as later revealed in Christ (John 14:23).

verses.text: The desire for Wisdom leads to a kingdom; loving her leads to friendship with God.
verses.comment: This verse directly links the pursuit of Wisdom to participating in God’s reign and having friendship with God, a relationship Christ offers in John 15:14-15.

verses.text: Honoring her keeps you from evil; following her teachings brings true love.
verses.comment: Obedience to Wisdom both protects from sin and brings about genuine love. This passage alludes to the transformative power of faithfully living out God’s commands.

verses.text: Loving her means keeping her laws; keeping her laws assures incorruptibility.
verses.comment: The love of God is concretely displayed in fidelity to His precepts; see how Jesus ties obedience to love in Matt. 19:17. Such obedience leads to spiritual incorruptibility.

verses.text: Incorruptibility brings one near to God.
verses.comment: Here, purity of life is directly connected to closeness with God. In Revelation 21:27, nothing impure will enter the heavenly Jerusalem.

verses.text: Desire for Wisdom thus leads to a kingdom. If therefore you delight in thrones and scepters, O rulers of the peoples, honor Wisdom so that you may reign forever.
verses.comment: The idea that true kingship and enduring rule are rooted in wisdom shows how godly authority is meant to flow from divine instruction. Alludes to the divine right of just rulers who seek God's Wisdom.

verses.text: I will declare what Wisdom is and how she came to be, and I will not hide mysteries from you, but will trace her course from the beginning of creation and make her knowledge clear, and I will not pass by the truth.
verses.comment: The author prepares to unveil deep mysteries, especially the origin and nature of divine Wisdom, echoing themes from Proverbs 8.

verses.text: Nor will I travel in company with envy, because such a person has nothing in common with Wisdom.
verses.comment: Envy is antithetical to wisdom, as later reiterated in James 3:14-16 which calls ‘envy and selfish ambition’ demonic. True wisdom is always pure, peaceable, gentle.

verses.text: A great number of wise people means the salvation of the world, and sensible kings ensure their people’s well-being.
verses.comment: Righteousness within a community brings blessing and even salvation (cf. Gen. 18). The idea of the well-being of the whole depending upon many wise men is echoed in the New Testament imagery of the Body of Christ. Suggestive of a visible, united spiritual leadership.

verses.text: Therefore, accept my words, and you will profit from them.
verses.comment: The chapter closes with a final exhortation to heed Wisdom, promising spiritual benefit. Reception of God’s truth leads to genuine life and spiritual health.
